page.title: 04TORONTO - PAST & PRESENT
page.content: This is a township in the Parish of St. Andrew Auckland, and was once called Newton Cap. A local business- man called Stobart, part owner of the local coal mine, and also on the Board of the Stockton & Darlington railway, was visiting his daughter in Toronto, in Canada in 1861 when news came that a rich seam had been discovered. He immediately decided to change the name of the mining village to Toronto. The operation reduced gradually until the mine finally closed in 1924. Since when the village has lost its school and village church. All that is left is a village store and public house. Now the famous viaduct (circa 1850) and a noble monument to the Railway Age is under threat of demolition by Durham County Council, a matter of great concern to the local residents who are rganising to stop these plans.
